Given your top priority, New Relic's strengths in transaction tracing and code-level profiling make it a great fit for your needs. Its ability to provide detailed insights into your API's performance bottlenecks will help you optimize response times and improve overall performance.

It's excellent that you're considering a trial or demo to get hands-on experience with both tools. This will give you a better understanding of how they integrate with your existing tech stack and which one aligns better with your team's workflow.

Before you start the trial, I recommend preparing a list of specific questions and scenarios to test during the evaluation period. This will help you make the most of the trial and ensure you're getting the insights you need to make an informed decision.

Some questions to consider:

1. How easily can I set up and integrate the tool with my existing infrastructure?
2. How detailed are the transaction tracing and code-level profiling features?
3. Can I easily identify performance bottlenecks and slow queries?
4. How does the tool handle complex distributed transactions and microservices?
5. What kind of support and resources are available for onboarding and troubleshooting?
6. How does the tool scale with our growing traffic and user base?
7. Are there any limitations or constraints on the number of users, transactions, or data retention?

By asking these questions and testing the tools, you'll be able to determine which one provides the best fit for your team's needs and helps you achieve your performance optimization goals.

Remember, it's essential to involve your team in the evaluation process to ensure everyone is comfortable with the chosen tool and can effectively use it to optimize your API's performance.

Good luck with the evaluation, and I hope you find the perfect tool to help NovaTech's project succeed!
